Subjective: Body tension, stiff muscles, rapid breathing, and heart palpitations for a few months, now daily for last 2 weeks. Palpitations are fast, regular, felt in neck; occur spontaneously at rest, not with exertion. Lasts ~30 mins, resolves spontaneously. Associated difficulty falling asleep due to worrying about work; sleeps ~6 hours on work nights, feels tired. Symptoms cause significant unrest. Worsened by coffee. Triggered by high-stress job as a new doctor with understaffing and long hours. Finds it difficult to say no. No chest pain, irregular heartbeat, dizziness, light-headedness, or abdominal complaints. Social: Doctor, works full-time. Good support system with friends/housemates who are also doctors. No smoking/alcohol mentioned. Request: Rule out physical cause like anemia; asks about talking to a professional.
Objective: Vitals: BP 120/60, HR 65, SpO2 98%, RR 14. General: Calm appearance. Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no abnormal sounds. Heart: Normal S1/S2, no murmurs. Abdomen: Not examined, no complaints.
Assessment: Stress-related physical symptoms secondary to work overload. Somatic causes to be ruled out.
Plan: 1. Blood tests: Hemoglobin, thyroid function, liver function, kidney function. 2. Referral: Appointment with mental health nurse. 3. Advice: Actively schedule relaxation moments. Maintain regular sleep schedule. Consider contacting occupational health doctor at hospital to discuss schedule adjustments. 4. Follow-up: Check blood results in 2 working days via phone or online portal. 5. Safety Net: Return if symptoms worsen or for any new concerns.
